ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course provided a broad overview of key concepts of macroeconomics, such as various long run growth models (Solow and Romer), inequality, models for firms and laborers' hiring/working practices, and the effects of fiscal and monetary policies. I also had practice with skills such as data analysis and the creation of basic graphs.

This class had super interesting content and I felt I came away with a good understanding of important macroeconomic, real-world topics. Although I had to take this for my major, I found it to be a really rewarding class. I know it would have been even more enjoyable in person.
I learned about the job search industry, consumption theory, inflation, fiscal and monetary policy, and inequality.
Learned some really cool economic models

Understanding of several macro-economic models and how they could be applied to real-world cases to better understand how our economy works. Focused on three area: 1) Long run, 2) inequality, 3) short run. The bulk of time was spent on 1 and 3, and all sections provided interesting background information and then ways to model and thus make further claims about the economy based on that information.
I learned to model long run economic growth, short run fluctuation, job market, automation, social mobility, among a variety of cool topics unseen in the AP.

- Labor Market theory
- Inequality
- Solow Model
- Romer Model
- AS-AD Model
- Game Theory behind Fed decision
Knowledge about economic growth
Built upon topics explored in intro macro with much more depth, such as the Solow (and Romer) model, the AS-AD framework, and the JCC-BC model of labor market.
Macroeconomics
Basic macro knowledge
Nothing

I gained more in depth familiarity with the models that were introduced in introductory macroeconomics. I learned how to apply mathematical equations to describe the economy and analyze shocks through a long run or short run framework.
Same concepts as intro macro, except with more algebra essentially
I learned more about macroeconomics.
I built off my econ skills from last semester and last year. We learned advanced equations and concepts.
I learned how to sift through a lot of data in excel in order to make calculations and make graphs
macroeconomic models and ideas
A deeper understanding of some economic models, monetary policy, GDP.
I learned about the various levers that the FED can pull to impact the economy at a macro level.
I learned some of the math behind macroeconomic topics including the classical model, the models of Solow and Romer, the labor market and search and matching model, and modern monetary policy.
Marcco econ
Long run models (Solow, Romer), labor and inequality, monetary policy
This course covers pretty much all the same topics as introductory macroeconomics but adds a slight twist to them. (i.e. Solow + Romer model, skill premium, AS-AD curve with shocks)
Deeper knowledge of macroeconomics and the economic tools used in macroeconomic analysis
I developed an understanding of equations modeling the concepts I learned in intro macro
I learned about macroeconomics and the underlying theories behind it.
I developed a deep understanding of macroeconomics and contemporary policy issues around everything from real interest rates to financial crises to labor markets and more.

I learned various central bank responses and how to analyze many macroeconomic events such as the Zero Lower Bound and Volcker Disinflation. We talked about both long run and short run models such as the solow-romer and AS-AD-IS models, respectively. I gained insights into fiscal and monetary policy, and about how those policies develop based on failures and successes in the past.
Knowledge of macroeconomics.
I got a broader view of macroeconomics and also learned how to create mathematical models of concepts.
Long run production models (Solow model, Romer model, Labor Supply and Demand, Job search model), Short run production models (business cycles, IS-MP, AS-AD model)

the classical economic model at equilibrium, the Solow Model, the Romer Model, the labor market, the labor market with search frictions, skill premiums, inequality, AS-AD model (savings, consumption, investments, monetary policy, fiscal policy, inflation, short-run cycles)
The course was divided into several sections: Solow Model, Romer Model, Inequality, and Business Cycles
math skills, critical thinking skills, broad macroeconomic topics

This course helped develop my knowledge of the base models used in understanding long-term growth, inequality measures, and the business cycle. This means things like growth factors as well as monetary policy methods and such.
Short run, and long run macroeconomics
Builds upon topics and concepts learned in intro macro with some supplemental lectures on professors research (not on the exam but very interesting)
Macroeconomics in the long run & short run, and inequalities. I learned to analyze the economy's growth, unemployment, monetary policies with models.
I gained a pretty good understanding of macro economic concepts such as monetary policy and different economic models such as Solow, Romer, etc.
The most insight I got was into how monetary policy works and its shortcomings given certain economic circumstances.

I learned how to evaluate macroeconomic trends on a financial and social level, perform computations specific to various long-term and short-term models, and think about how supply/demand/technology shocks affect the economy.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures were sometimes a bit all over the place and it was sometimes hard to consolidate the takeaways from each class.

This course often took large tangents away from the core material. It would have been nice to save these as optional at the end of class or for extra days. It often made the material more confusing and application in psets more difficult.

Strengths: great content
Weaknesses: wish we had done more applied stuff in lecture, rather than solely in section

Strengths:
Very clear lectures during which the professor was always willing to answer questions or clarify content. Covered interesting material and makes you a much better informed citizen, as the stuff talked about in this class is constantly in the news. PSETS had a nice mix of theoretical and data handling questions which both helped understand/extend the theories in class as well as see how they corresponded to real world empirical phenomena. The structure of the course by and large was good, with us moving on from a model after we saw its deficiencies and progressing to a model which clarified those deficiencies. 
Weaknesses:
The biggest weakness I would say is that although generally good, the structuring sometimes felt a little bit unmotivated. This was especially true in the inequality section, where although the information was quite interesting, it felt somewhat detached from the other two parts of the course. Maybe this is inevitable, but if so then it was weird to put it in-between the short and long-run sections of the course which somewhat naturally connected.

Strengths: psets are really helpful, Fabrizio cares about his students (he tries not to pace himself too fast), and Pedro is a gem!
Weaknesses: perhaps the final is weighed a bit much, but I think it is very fair

Strengths:
- Very fair
- Clear, structured content
- Very communicative
- Section helpful

Weaknesses:
- Some parts of exam were all or nothing which may not be good for curve
Exams were difficult
Professor was very engaging and attentive to student questions. Sections were also often useful and helped recap important topics.
The class gives a good overview of the material. The exams are a bit fast

The course was everything that I expected it to be, it had clear lectures and weekly problem sets. Overall, there were many resources and the whole teaching staff made learning macroeconomics quite enjoyable. One improvement I could suggest is to decrease the weight of the final exam which is worth 50% of the final grade. This could be a source of stress to many students but I understand that the course is graded on a curve so it is still a fair policy.

Strengths - fabrizzio is a great lecturer - he paced the content at good pace and explained everything intuitively.
I wish we did more real world applications. Not sure the significance of all this.
The class went very fast--I think Professor Zilibotti treated us more like grad students than undergraduate students. The tests were also very difficult.
Strength was the lecture being recorded. The resources to study are easily accessible on canvas.

- strengths: the tfs were all wonderful and tried their best to teach us the material even when it was really confusing
- weaknesses: 1) there were no actual review sessions for either the midterm or final and instead they just held office hours; I feel like this arrangement made it much harder to study for the exams 2) sometimes the tfs would not even know the answer to some of the questions on the practice exams or couldn't really explain some concepts; made it very frustrating for us as students to understand it if those who were teaching us didn't know what was going on either

The ppt slides contain relatively few information, making it hard to serve as a review material for the exams. But other than that, I've learnt a lot about macroeconomics and really enjoyed the process in the course.
I honestly just did not like the class very much.

Instructors really cared about student feedback and lightened the course load, which was really appreciated. It can feel like a lot of work and overwhelm you a bit, but overall the virtual format was well taught.

The course was taught well and the topics were interesting. The TAs were extremely helpful -- sections and office hours were great. The p-sets were a bit on the lengthy side given that they were due each week rather than every two weeks, but other than that, there is nothing that could be improved.
Poor professor

Fabrizio's slides aren't that great. Pretty confusing. Especially since many slides were split up into a bunch with animation-like things, when they were posted to canvas like that, reviewing them was pretty difficult since there'd be like 100 slides but only 30 with unique information

Strengths: Well organized, teaching was very clear, and Prof Zilibotti made the material interesting. I appreciated that we could drop two psets. 
Weaknesses: The problem sets were fairly inconsistent in length - some were really long. Also, I thought that on the psets (and sometimes exams too) there was perhaps a bit too much emphasis on doing algebra correctly instead of the economic principles

Fabrizio was very kind and genuinely wanted students to enjoy learning macroeconomics, and the TA's and peer tutors were great. That being said, this was likely the hardest course I've taken at Yale. Even though I met the prerequisite and reviewed over break, I did not feel mathematically prepared for this course nor expected to have so much Excel graphing without that being taught in class. I had not taken intermediate micro (not a prereq) but I feel it was assumed we knew some of those skills. Sections were devoted to learning how to actually solve problems rather than review, and I would not have gotten through this course without attending multiple office hours every week. I prepared extensively for the exam, but did not feel it completely paid off.

Strengths: Helpful T.A.s, good practice questions provided

Weaknesses: Lectures were very conceptual and did not run through the mathematical problems found on the exams, explanations were sometimes not very clear

This course is strength was its organization. We spent a few weeks on long run, a few weeks on inequality, and closed the class with a few weeks on short run. One weakness of this course would be the slides and presentation of course material. Oftentimes, methods outlined in class would deviate from methods outlined in section which would also deviate from what we saw on our problem sets. There was also not much time given to the intuition behind models, and more time spent evaluating what types of problems we could encounter when using the model.
I liked the instructor and the teaching style. I think that the class should have been cut with more assessments, like a second midterm -- it was too much to have 50% rely on the final.

I do not think I got as much out of this class as I could have. Now I have a lot of sympathy for professors teaching during the pandemic and I'm sure it must be hard to hold lectures over zoom, but there were some issues I had with the class. First, I think Fabrizio has a very indirect way of lecturing where he will introduce a model, but then 3 slides later, say that the model is incorrect and the real model is as follows. This will effectively make all of my notes up until that point useless. This is something he does for almost every model he introduces in the class (sometimes re-teaching a model multiple times within the same class), and as a result when I went over my notes to study for the final, I found them to be very disorganized and almost useless. I ended up rewriting my notes in a more organized manner just for the final. On a similar note, I found the lecture slides to be rather disorganized and difficult to distinguish the key concepts from the less-important material (eg. scratch work for deriving an equation). For example, we would often spend a ton of time examining some line graph (which ended up never being mentioned again in the rest of the semester), before rushing through 10 slides about a concept that was crucial to the problem set. I think this could be improved by periodically including summary slides or key concept slides to highlight the important takeaways (this is something he started doing later on in the semester, and I think that was a step in the right direction). The final for this class is also worth 50% of the grade, which is understandable since it is cumulative, but I personally thought it was too much since combined with the midterm it made the problem sets in the class worth almost nothing.

Its weaknesses are its psets (which were mostly just moving around variables and manipulating equations - glorified algebra) and lectures often made concepts more difficult than they could be. Slides were tough to study bc they didnt have much content on them
The course had pretty strong TAs; I would say a weakness of the course was that there were a lot of problem sets.

This course is extremely difficult. I think that the depth of the teaching in lecture often did not match the difficulty of the problem sets or exam questions. I often found myself having to rewatch the lectures multiple times, research topics on my own, or pursue hours and hours of separate office hours time to stay on top of the course material. It is misleading to think that this course requires only two lecture slots and a section. I would say I had to dedicate about 50% of my studying time to this course, even though I was taking four other classes this semester. Another major weakness was thatwith a number of notable exceptionsthe TAs really did not know how to answer many of our questions. They worked really hard on ED to answer everything, and the students really appreciated that, but they often didn't know the answers to Problem Set questions because they were just too hard. I think this was more of an issue with the overall difficulty of the course than the economic knowledge of the TAs.

Strengths: Organized lecture plan and lots of material covered
Weaknesses: Not much interaction with other students nor professor.
Needs more emphasis on the exam material in the lectures. Need to slow down the material too.

I thought that the lectures were engaging and the problem sets were helpful. However, I felt like the class was a bit too theoretical and therefore difficult to get a grasp of at times. It was much more math heavy than I anticipated, but the slides in lecture and section were very comprehensive.

The course was well structured and interesting. Professor Zilibotti was very positive and helpful in responding to asks for help. There are lots of TAs and office hours available during the week. ED (online platform where we asked course related questions) was also helpful. 

The course is almost perfect, with the exception of how stressful it is. I enjoyed the problem sets and didn't mind the high workload throughout, but the tests were extremely difficult and made the course stressful--they go far beyond than what was just covered in lecture. Even though the problem sets all made sense, the exams themselves were still difficult even after a lot of studying. Moreover, the curve for the course does not seem to be that generous because some people do well on the exams. Given pandemic times and the fact that everyone is studying under different conditions with different home life situations, the curve (which evaluates you against other students) does not seem to be fair.
class was well paced, not much to say
Strengths included interesting and relevant topics; weaknesses were that the grading system really does not captures students' understanding of the material.

Strengths: Straightforward grading system, 2 dropped P-Sets allowed, lecture slides were fairly well done.
Weaknesses: Sections were not recorded, minimal feedback on problem sets,

Strengths: organization, TA section, practice problems, clarity
Weaknesses: more practice problems throughout the semester

Strengths: Any theory is supplemented with real-world statistics to enhance understanding. Topics are covered in detail. Weaknesses: Not a lot of time going through more nuanced versions of the models that are typically similar to those found on exams.

Strengths: prof cares a lot about his students and making sure we understood the material, class material is pretty interesting and the math was fun for the most part (its basically just first order derivatives and algebraic manipulations so way less intense than intermediate macro), TFs were great (shoutout to my main man Jihoon)

Weaknesses: psets could get really long sometimes and they were really lenient with grading which was bittersweet because it was good for boosting that 20% of our grade but meant that using the psets to study off of wasnt helpful sometimes, the EXAMS omg no exam should be worth 50% of your total grade and the fact that the final was intentionally too long for most of the class to finish AND we didnt get our grades back we just got the final grade

The combination of lecture and discussion section keeps me engaged in this course. The structure of this course (three parts: long-run, inequalities, short-run) is designed well so that every new concept is understandable.

Weakness: This course was basically a glorified algebra class. Although it was better than intermediate micro, the number of times where I was just doing rote algebra was frustrating. It would have been much more interesting to have a better understanding of the big picture of different concepts before delving into the more tedious algebra.

Strengths: Better insight on how the FED uses monetary policy and the government uses fiscal policy to affect inflation rates and causes recessions or booms in the economy. It was also somewhat interesting the learn the Solow and Romer models to understand factors for short and long-run economic growth. If Jihoon is still a TF, definitely attend his section and office hours! He was always so prepared and an absolute gem. Not only could I have basically learned the entire class from simply attending his section, but I was able to understand and complete my problem sets during his office hours.
The discussion sections led by the TFs were extremely helpful in understanding the material. Workload overall seemed manageable throughout the semester. The course was also well structured.

The course focuses a lot on the theory of what we study which is great. When it comes to the midterm and final, however, it is by far the mathematics that somewhat applies to the theory that is being tested. This makes it very punishing for students who might slip up once and instantly fall significantly due to the high curve. Instead, if a lot more theory was tested a lot more economic thinking would be tested instead of math ability. This is an econ class after all.

The course did a great job teaching students about the macroeconomics behind the COVID-19 pandemic while sticking to the material taught in past lectures. The faculty did a great job accommodating students who had a difficult time learning virtually and setting up private meetings.

Still, the course could have been structured better. First, the lecture titles and numbers were so disorganized that it made reviewing exam material very difficult. Some of the lectures were even combined into one massive lecture with over a hundred slides towards the end of the course. Second, the course needs to do a better job of facilitating group work. Despite being assigned to a study group, I had to work on problem sets alone due to a lack of responsiveness from other students. Beyond assigning the groups, the course staff needs to find a way to check in on them in order to ensure that students like myself are not at a disadvantage. Third, the professor did not do a good job of clarifying what exam material we needed to know from the lectures. Some of his lectures were completely irrelevant because they were about current market events not being tested or his own research.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought that having recorded lectures were very helpful - even though they created a risk of falling behind, it was nice to be able to look back in case I missed anything. I wonder if it might have been better to have more midterm exams and reduce the weight of the two exams we did have, given the pandemic. That way, each one would have lower stakes and if people had particularly challenging weeks prior to an exam it would not affect their grades too much. However, the instructors did adjust the grading scheme so that two problem sets could be dropped.
Testing was fine, liked the recorded lecture option
Honestly, this course was fine to take over Zoom; just engagement is really hard over Zoom in general
The professor did two review sessions to allow people to absorb the materials, which I think was really helpful
Recorded lectures helped
Although I attended the lectures live, having the recorded version to look back at while studying was quite helpful.
I enjoyed the lectures reserved for questions

I thought the professor did a great job allowing for student questions and engagement during lectures as well as in office hours. The abundance of TF office hours were also a good place to get individual help.
NA
I think the learning would be mostly equal online and in person for this course.

- needs improvement: definitely needed to have proper review sessions, sections should have been recorded, the testing process was unnecessarily tedious
- done well: after noticing how much stress we were in, Fabrizio cut down the number of psets required

Succeeded: Lectures
Need to be improved: the different discussion sections vary a lot in quality. It would be better if there's any way we can see the past students' evaluations of these TA before we sign up for a discussion section.
i like that it was recorded
Various changes introduced by the instructors (open-book tests, for example) were very much appreciated and alleviated the pressure
The virtual format actually worked very well. Lectures were generally engaging and sections were very helpful.
Dropping psets was really helpful!

Though I understand that the professor wanted to diminish cheating, having Zoom open during the 3 hr exam was incredibly distracting. While I appreciate the kind problem set grading, it did make it more difficult to prepare for exams.
The online lectures were sometimes not very relevant to the problem sets and exams. The T.A.'s office hours were very helpful.

I found the strictness of the exams over zoom to be incredibly excessive given that the exams are open book open note. I did appreciate that exams were open book, and that there were plenty of sections for time zones
It was great that office hours were online because we could just attend them at our own convenience without having to travel across campus.

Discussion sections were extremely helpful and a huge success, as they provided an opportunity to ask questions about the material that were not only clarifying, but also expansive on the material covered.
Swift availability of slides and lectures was helpful.
I thought that the lectures and sections were organized well for COVID, but the lectures could have been a bit more dynamic to facilitate more engagement.

Given pandemic times and the fact that everyone is studying under different conditions with different home life situations, the curve (which evaluates you against other students) does not seem to be fair.
recorded lectures are always convenient
The exams should either be shorter or take home. The length of the exam for how little time is provided completely fails to achieve its aim of assessing students' understanding of the material.
Sections should have been recorded
The TA sections were very organized and engaging. Professor Zilibotti was very understanding to our needs throughout the semester and made accommodations for late PSETS/extensions.
The recording of lectures was incredibly helpful throughout the pandemic. It allowed more flexibility.
Everything was just shifted to Zoom. There werent really any changes to engage students more virtually
The permission for async attendance, as well as the wide range of time slots of discussion sections, is great for students in other time zones.
Recorded lectures were particularly helpful during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The sections felt very dry and impersonal. If there would be a way to improve those during covid (although it doesn't matter now) it would help improve the class.
A big selection of office hours was by far the most helpful practice in the virtual learning environment.
The virtual lectures and sections were consistent throughout the semester. But the course staff did not follow up with the study groups they helped facilitate enough.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is a good course for a major, but there are many other economic courses that are interesting if you are taking this as an elective.

Not with Professor Zilibotti - he struggles to distill simpler topics, and although he takes questions during lecture, by that point one is too lost to even know what to ask. Additionally, examples are rarely included during lectures, meaning that weekly office hours are a must for completing the pset.

Many students likely take this course because of major requirements. However, I would say that I think this course can be very good for a student to determine whether he or she really likes economics - it discusses major principles while also exposing students to mathematical tools (including data analysis). Thus, I would not recommend this course for someone wanting a basic and simple background in macroeconomics, but I would recommend it to someone who is interested in seeing what macroeconomics really is about and whether economics is the field for them.
It's a requirement
Yes I would recommend this class -- super interesting and not a terrible workload.
Not necessarily. Only if it is as a requirement or you really enjoy the material and are up for the challenge
Yes! I was reading about inflation today and I was like wow I actually know why inflation is scary for investors... because interest rates will increase.
Yes. Good overview of important and topical macro-economic questions, with PSETS that most of the time actually help better understand the material, all without being a work/time overload.
I would definitely recommend it to majors and non-majors. The module on inequality is very fascinating.
Yes, you will learn macro and learn it well, the right way. Professor can be harsh but professor really cares you actually learn
If you are an Econ majors
Absolutely. Even those not majoring in economics, but who are interested in public policy, should take this course.
Yes, this course is well organized and well taught
it was interesting, but only take if required for your major.
Never with this professor

I would recommend this course to another student. It is a core course in economics which means most students in the major will take it. It is useful for learning the important models of economics and the lectures are very informational and clear.
If you have to take it yes! If not, just take intro macro
It is a requirement for the Econ major. Otherwise, no.
Unless an econ major, I would not recommend this class. This is a tough course with advanced lessons. However, this is a necessary and useful class if interested in economics.
No; only take it if you need it for your major or are just so absolutely great at math (but even in that case, I bet there are more interesting math classes to take)
Yes, it's a very nice intermediate macro course. Very useful and very interesting.
Only if you have to take it. Also if you like math

Only for major requirements / if you are really passionate. Prof Zilibotti is great and is a good lecturer, and communicates very clearly (and the TAs are massively helpful as well). Overall, the structure is good and the material is useful, but it is a lot of work and can at times feel overwhelming, particularly if you are not very comfortable with math.
Yes. The course is structured well to aid in learning. It was also engaging and interesting.

Yes, if you're interested in macroeconomics, especially monetary policy, and if you don't mind a bit of algebra, this course is worthwhile. It was substantially more satisfying than introductory macro, which introduced these same topics but did not provide much mathematical intuition at all. The monetary policy unit was especially enlightening and is very applicable to the news etc.
Poor professor
Cause u have to take it, ya

Yes! I assume you're taking this because it is required, but it was honestly one of the best taught econ required classes I have taken. Prof Zilibotti is really good, he explains everything really well and is also very approachable.
I would not recommend this course to another student because the lectures do not prepare one very well for the problem sets and final exams.

As with many of the economics core required courses, take this class if you would like a degree in economics but not if you are looking for a fun and engaging overview of the world economy. I believe that the casual economist would be much better suited by taking introductory macro, and then delving into some specific electives rather than taking intermediate macro.
Yes, especially if you have a background interest in macroeconomics. As someone who is interested in macroeconomics (and is an econ major), I enjoyed Prof. Zilibotti and this teaching team.
No. I took it because I thought I liked intro macro and wanted to see if I want to tack on an Econ major. I dont anymore.
I would only recommend it if you're taking it for a major.

I would just be cautious if you're going to take this course. It is among the hardest classes I have taken at Yale. I would recommend making sure you have enough time bracketed out in your semester to complete this course. The concepts hurt your brain, and the exams/problem sets are really not easy.
Yes! Great macroeconomic class to start with. I look forward to continuing down the line with more econ/finance courses that build on the knowledge I gained in this course.
I would recommend it but would advise the student to be aware of how mathematical it is. For a broader view of macroeconomics concepts without these models, I would suggest they look elsewhere.
Take it if you need it/ love macroeconomics.

This class is required for the economics major. I would recommend taking it with Prof. Zilibotti. He does a good job of explaining the concepts and trying his best to ensure that no one gets left behind. 

I would caution that this class is very high workload and intellectually challenging.
I would recommend the course to another student. It supplements the basic topics learned in introductory macroeconomics with greater mathematical rigor.

The material is very interesting, but you usually dont understand it the first-time around. Only when you review your notes, do the problem sets, and study for exams do things start clicking. I think a lot depends on the TF too  make sure you pick a good one! Tough exams!
Yes
Yes. It is a great course that teaches the intuition for macroeconomic factors that you will need need in other courses.
Yes! Fabrizio is a great lecturer and covers many interesting areas of macroeconomics.

I mean if youre considering this course, you probably have to take it. I had to take it for my major but I had the option to take this or intermediate micro and I will say Id always recommend macro over micro because the concepts are more applicable in everyday life and understanding world economics. If for some reason youre looking for a QR and think this class would be best to fill it, Id highly recommend choosing a course that isnt as constantly strenuous (psets start the first week).

Yes. I will recommend it to anyone who is interested in the mechanism behind macroeconomics. This course provides a unique insight into the methodology behind economics -- every conclusion is deduced from existing models.

If you're not an Economics major, there really isn't a need to take this course. Taking intro macro will allow you to understand the big picture without the tedious algebra (which doesn't really contribute to a deeper understanding of the material).
I would recommend this course to other students. It expands on the material from introductory macroeconomics and helps you see the mathematical logic behind theories.

No. I am an economics major and I do not enjoy the core econ-major courses. Other econ courses do a better job of engaging students with the material and do not make it all about testing your math ability to determine your grade. Introduction to Game Theory is an example of an econ class that is also based on math but makes the teaching and even testing of the material far more engaging than the core courses.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lectures were recorded
live virtual lecture
In addition to a live virtual lecture, I attended weekly live virtual sections.
Sections
I only watched recordings of lectures and attended section synchronously b/c those weren't recorded
Also had virtual sections once a week with a TF (both the lectures and sections were recorded for those who could not attend live)
Just lectures
- Weekly section
sections
live virtual lectures that were recorded for asynchronous viewing
Zoom lecture
N/A
In addition to live virtual lectures, there were live virtual discussion sections.
NA
It was a live virtual lecture, but there were 1-2 recorded lectures we had to watch, too.
weekly section

- weekly section with teaching fellows
- office hours
recorded lecture, not recorded section
Recorded lecture.
Weekly virtual discussion sections
Section
Live virtual lecture plus weekly section
Lectures were also recorded
Lectures were also recorded and could be viewed asynchronously.
TA Hours, discussion sections, office hours
I attended live virtual lectures and live virtual sections.
Recorded lecture, section (must be attended live)
Virtual discussion section
live section
Recorded lecture
Lectures were recorded
recorded lecture as well
live virtual section
recorded lecture
Virtual discussion section
I started by attending live virtual lectures but slowly transitioned to recorded lectures by the end of the semester.
Lectures were held live but also recorded.
Live lecture with the ability to rewatch or watch after to accommodate covid situations.
The course also featured an in-person section.
